ratings.comment: Prof. Hyer definitely cares about his students, but take note: his emails and writing both DON'T match up in tone with how he is in person. He often makes things sound super consequential/scary in an effort to make sure people take them seriously; if you're genuinely struggling, ASK him. He's surprisingly understanding IF you advocate for yourself.

Professor Hyer is a criminally underrated professor who pours a lot of thought into his course and who truly cares about his students. He gets a bad rep for his rather subjective way of grading; however, he's always happy to answer questions and explains everything extremely well. Pay attention and ask questions, and you will succeed.

You can tell Professor Hyer really understands and loves music theory, but he can get ahead of himself. He thinks what he teaches is easy when in reality it is harder to grasp for the majority of students. You should reach out if you are struggling as he is willing to help you, but this class is difficult regardless. The papers are also a struggle.
He can be a tough professor. He says the truth and some people found him mean for it. Work hard and you will have a good time. Ask him for help, he is always willing to give good advice.
Hard first music theory class. You get used to how he wants things, but it is a lot of work.

Hyer is a fantastic musician and he is very good at explaining concepts. The only problem is that he is quite subjective in his grading especially when grading papers (which are a huge part of your final grade). You really have to conform to his style of writing and thinking about music. Class is hard, but if you genuinely work hard you will pass.

I didn't expect music theory to be easy, but the difficulty of this class blew me away. However, Prof. Hyer is a very caring, if not easily-understood, instructor. He knows everyone in his classes by name and gives detailed feedback on assignments that he grades, like essays. Anyone struggling in this class needs to go to office hours.

Not everyone gives him a fair shot, but he's an awesome person and a great professor. Unfortunately a lot of music majors don't have great study habits, but if you actually do the readings it's a fairly simple class. My only grievance is you have to cater your papers to the way that he speaks, but you get used to it after a while.

He is very passionate about music and he clearly tries to impart that onto us. However, he expects us to see the layers and all the little things he sees. I really like him but his high expectations make it difficult to do well. If you don't read scores well or don't hear everything you'll struggle quite a bit.

This class is a very basic theory class that you cannot test out of even if you know all the information. Professor Hyer teaches it very poorly and slowly, and lots of standard music theory formatting is disregarded for the textbook's formatting. Also, papers are unnecessarily long and subjectively graded with little regard to content.

I came out of this class confused. If it wasn't required for a music major, I would have dropped. I don't consider myself lazy by any stretch, but his papers were hard, and honestly I thought his grading was biased towards specific verbs. Yes, verbs. As it's required, the best advice I can give you is to go to lecture always. Write papers his way.

Brian Hyer is a great professor! He is very knowledgeable and does a great job explaining concepts in lecture. Papers were a lot of work but were a good way of applying everything you learn. If you put in the work and ask questions you will do fine. Dont miss lecture

Hyer is brilliant and deeply understands music. I have had health problems in this semester, and been unable work to my potential. He's offered a lot of opportunities for me to succeed. Caring. However, he is a challenging professor and expects a lot out of his students. The papers are tough, learn what he likes to read and say and stick to that.

Lecture style is engaging, but content is immensely difficult and graded harshly.  Lengthy assignments are handed out twice a week, but they're not just busy work.  Overall, a very tough grader, but an enjoyable professor to work with and an adept teaching style.
Great teacher really cares about students

Do the work and you will likely get a B. Keep up in class, write the papers ect. Very challenging to get anything above a B. Especially because homework is weighted very heavily and TA's grade pretty difficultly.

Professor Hyer is absolutely terrible. He assigns papers that should be opinionated, but if it's not what he agrees with then it's wrong. Worst professor I've ever had. Dropped my music major because of him.

You really have to know basic theory before taking this- all the basics, including the ability to sing basic melodies, and hear a lot of things with accuracy,is assumed. It's a tough learning curve at the beginning if you have no previous theory experience. Lectures are extremely helpful- he practically gives you the answers/ what he's looking for.

Officially the worst theory professor I have ever had. Very poorly taught, and filled with unconventional content when it comes to tonal theory. If you come in to the course with no theory background, you will do badly because they do not cover basics. If you know anything about theory, it will conflict with what he tries to teach you.

Prof. Hyer is a nice man who is very knowledgeable and well-respected in the music theory world.  However, the subjects taught in this class are not revelant to actual music performance.  Additionally, the professor assigns grades on an extremely arbitrary basis; once he forms an opinion of you, your grade will be what he wants it to be.

Professor Hyer really knows his stuff. In terms of knowledge, you can't get much better than him. The downside is that he tends to think that if you don't agree with him, you're wrong. Not in a derogatory way or anything, but he thinks his analysis is right, and pretty much anything else isn't.

A brilliant individual and a caring person. The debate over utility of his introductory theory class aside, it is an interesting and engaging class, and his dedication to his pedagogical principles and is students is admirable. Schenkerian analysis is well worth it if you're up for something really demanding.
A helpful and thoughtful man.  If you don't understand something, he will explain it to you effectively.  Extremely knowledeable musician.

Stay away from this class if you can. The material taught in this class is useless and the assignments and papers a big waste of time. If you have a chance to go to another music school do it. This class will put you at a disadvantage for the future.

This class was very hard. Lots of assignments and the papers are very difficult. You need to get yourself into Prof Hyer's mindset and think like him if you want to do well. However, he is always willing to help you and practically show you what he wants on the papers as long as you go and ask him. Work hard and study and you'll do fine!

This professor should be fired . He is by far the worst teacher at the University of Wisconsin Madison. He comes across like he cares but he is a big fake and unfortunately many students have had to endure this class which puts them at a disadvantage for the rest of the class due to the poor quality of teaching and choice of curriculum .

This is definitely a horrible class to take especially trying to figure out what the hell he wants on his assignments! Most of the times I can't figure out why other students get better grades than what I got. This guy can't teach a standard Music theory class and we have to write papers in a theory class! I thought papers are written in Mus Hist!

Nice guy, but it's impossible to know what he wants on papers.He dismisses topics he doesn't agree with and sometimes doesn't clarify and answer questions.  Will not concede his point, even when a good counter-argument if brought up. Don't take it if you don't need to!
Wow...this class was pointless...professer sucked

He is very knowledgeable and enthusiastic, but a little too earnest.  He expects his freshman to come into theory 121 w/ a good backward in music theory. A very hard course for freshman.  A challenging grader and has an entire different outlook on writing papers than most english teachers.

Professor Hyer- knowledgeable about course material, willing to help outside of class.  Superficial enthusiam that made course boring at times.  Somewhat condescending/pretentious at times.  Paper assignments: use solid supportive material, grading rewards well-developed, persuasive arguments.

Prof Hyer is very knowledgable and is willing to help anyone. He is a very good teacher but a hard grader. The key to this class is to figure out the way he thinks about music and to try to mimic that in your writing. Once you do that you will have mastered the class. I am still working at it.

He’s very knowledgeable, and the class is interesting at times.  But the assignments are just overkill, and each one is difficult to get an A on.  You need a good TA, and that’s that.  Other than that though, he’s a pretty interesting guy to talk to.

defintely knows what he's talking about, and very willing to help if you're having problems. the "practical" aims of the class are helpful (you learn how to apply concepts in REAL situations), but he avoids addressing some topics directly, dismissing them as unimportant - but most grad school assume u know these topics.. you can see the problem

He obviously knows what he is talking about, but overall the expectations of the assignments are never clear and the grades are generally low.  Papers are very unclear as to what he wants, so good luck even though it won't help.  Hope that you get a good TA otherwise you're screwed.

Very clear with everything and very willing to help you with any problems you have.  Tough on grading papers, but not unreasonably.  Really tried to make the class fun too, and succeeded most of the time, I think.
I almost dropped the music major because of him. Watch out.
He definitely knows his stuff, but as a teacher he's too dogmatic and inflexible.

Hyer genuinely tries to make the class interesting and fun; unfortunately, that's hard to do with theory. His grading is tough, though; it's hard to know what he's looking for. He's big on clarity and organization in papers, so make sure you revise them a lot and focus only on important things.
I really enjoy his teaching.  He's a harsh grader (he expects too much), but he is very clear in what he wants and how he teaches.  Highly recommended.
No Comments
Hated him. He should not be teaching frosh. Everything had to be his way, and his explanations were too arcane. Needs to respect his students and get the stick out of his rear.
No Comments
No Comments
